text: FAMILY MEMBER: Oh. Okay. Right. I just wanted to clarify.
PATIENT: But I went out to, uh, to see how, how to walk because sometimes it was difficult walking especially with this leg here. And, uh, I don’t, I don’t know, I had a whole lot of pep in my step-
DOCTOR: Okay.

PATIENT: - going down and coming back, and, uh, my daughter said you don’t seem like you feel anything. I said, no, I feel pretty good there. And, uh, so I do have those particular days, but then I have those days as well. I said, oh, man, when this day going to be over with so I can go to bed tonight
DOCTOR: Is that because of pain that those days are hard for you?

PATIENT: Sometimes it’s, it’s pain, but a lot of the areas that I wasn’t haven’t pain in, uh, not much anymore. My heel on my left side was having a lot of pain that I think I had shared, and, uh, I still have some if I go and overdo it, but other than that, no, my shoulders every now and then. My biggest challenge now is, is getting a good night’s sleep.
DOCTOR: Okay.

PATIENT: And that’s because I’ve tried a number of different ways on how to sleep in the bed. I, I have these pillows that I prop up with a long pillow there, to try to lean up against the back of it so, I, you know, my back is up against the pillow. It works some nights. Some nights it doesn’t work.
DOCTOR: Okay. And so you’re having trouble falling asleep or is it that you fall asleep and then you, you’re waking up with-?
PATIENT: Well, I wake back up. And sometimes if, uh, you know how you try to get in a comfortable position? It’s trying to find that comfortable position for that night.
DOCTOR: So you’re waking up because of pain?
PATIENT: Uh, not pain all the time. Sometimes it’s just, uh, what’s the term I’m looking for?
DOCTOR: Discomfort?

PATIENT: Yeah. You know? And, uh, just trying to get in a place where you feel like this is where I need to be at, I’m happy here. So, uh, uh, one of the best sleeping place, and I hate to say it, is my living room downstairs on the couch. I prop the pillows up, and, uh, and got my favorite space, so when I lay down and put my back up right up against the back of it, but I don’t want to be in the business of sleeping on my living room couch every night, either. We have a sleep number bed that we purchased just for this, but, uh, uh, I wouldn’t recommend sleep number being if that’s what you’re going, you’re going to use it for, because it’s not all it’s, it’s cut out to be. You’re paying a lot of money for a bed. And sometimes it works, sometimes it don’t. So my biggest challenge each night is to figure out, okay, what’s going to work tonight? Is my Lazy Boy going to work? Uh, I even tried the floor with my granddaughter’s, uh, what do you call those things she has?
PATIENT: Um hum. Okay. I think we’re on the same page.
DOCTOR: Comfortable with that?
PATIENT: I am.
DOCTOR: More importantly, is your wife comfortable with that?
PATIENT: Well, I’m looking at her right now. Go ahead and say what you have to say. (chuckles)
FAMILY MEMBER: No. I mean, well, yeah, at the end. But I’m fine with whatever you want to do, but I had a question –
DOCTOR: Um hum.
FAMILY MEMBER: - about, uh, why do you think the PSA is continuing to grow or get higher with, uh, with him being on the medication? That’s the part that I’m not quite, uh, I don’t understand.

DOCTOR: I mean, the most likely explanation is that the cancer is continuing to grow at a slow pace. In other words, maybe the pace of the growth has slowed down, but it’s still growing overall, which is why I said that there are a few disconnects in my own mind about this therapy is working around.
FAMILY MEMBER: Um hum.
DOCTOR: On the one hand, the PSA would lead me to believe that it wasn’t, but the scans would lead me to believe, that at the very least, we achieved the stability.
PATIENT: Um hum.
DOCTOR: So, but I, I agree with you that, that usually, although not always, usually the PSA that is rising means that the cancer is growing overall.
PATIENT: Um hum.
PATIENT: Um hum.
DOCTOR: So that’s something to keep in mind. That’s why I’m not placing like all the emphasis on the PSA, but I’m certainly placing some emphasis on it, uh.
FAMILY MEMBER: And so as a layperson, that’s all we have. You know?
DOCTOR: Yeah.

FAMILY MEMBER: That’s, that’s the only way when he gets his blood test and it comes back and, you know, you said, oh, gosh, the PSA has risen again. You know? That’s our only frame of reference as to where we are in all this and what the cancer is doing.
DOCTOR: There’s no question that we would have preferred it would have dropped.
PATIENT: Um hum.

DOCTOR: But the absence of a drop does not necessarily mean the drug hasn’t worked. It, it might mean that the drug has not worked as well as we had hoped or anticipated, uh, but it might still be doing something, or it might take longer to work. To start working the drug may have to build up in your system.
PATIENT: Um hum.

DOCTOR: Or in your case, you haven’t really been on a full dose, and you’ve had these interruptions where you’ve been, you know, totally off of it for three weeks, you know? And now for another two weeks. So.
PATIENT: Um hum.
FAMILY MEMBER: So when he comes back on September fifth, the two-hundred milligrams will be here, so he can take it with him that day?
DOCTOR: Yes. That’s the plan. Provided that the hemoglobin is sufficient.
PATIENT: Um hum.

DOCTOR: I know. All by yourself.

DOCTOR: How come I’m over here?
PATIENT: You can’t get these things together. Do you need me to get together or what? (Laughter)
PATIENT: No.
DOCTOR: What do I have to get together again? What? Hey, you guys are wearing the same shirt.
FAMILY MEMBER: Yes.
DOCTOR: Is that on purpose for filming?
FAMILY MEMBER: No. Oh, I don’t know. (Laughter)
DOCTOR: Okay. I was just checking. My other couple also dressed up but she was in blue and he was in pink.
FAMILY MEMBER: Oh.
DOCTOR: It looked like they should be in a catalog.
FAMILY MEMBER: Right.
FAMILY MEMBER: Right.
DOCTOR: So, I wasn’t sure if it was like Tigers day or.
FAMILY MEMBER: I know. Yes.
DOCTOR: Okay.
PATIENT: Just working zone. (Laughter)
DOCTOR: How you feeling?
PATIENT: I’ve been great.
DOCTOR: The rest of your labs are fine, but, you know, your PSA is trickling up, four point two.
FAMILY MEMBER: Oh.
DOCTOR: Now, in March, you were at two and a half.
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: And I know that we want to be as aggressive as possible with you.
FAMILY MEMBER: Yes.
DOCTOR: Because sometimes when your disease decides to do something, we need to quiet it down quick.
FAMILY MEMBER: Oh.
FAMILY MEMBER: Oh, okay.
DOCTOR: In case. Now, it wasn’t like you went all the way down zero and stayed there. So you were always around a one to two.
PATIENT: Um hum.
DOCTOR: You know? You’re in the fours a couple of times now, so.
PATIENT: Um hum. Could it be because I’ll be in the sun a lot?
DOCTOR: No.
FAMILY MEMBER: Right.
DOCTOR: Not that. You’re doing everything right. You are.
DOCTOR: Everything from the music to showing up when you’re supposed to. You’re doing all the right things.
PATIENT: Hum.
DOCTOR: You really are. It’s just that the cancer doesn’t care.
PATIENT: I get it.
DOCTOR: It’s the cancer that’s doing all bad things. I care.
FAMILY MEMBER: Right.
FAMILY MEMBER: Right.
DOCTOR: The cancer doesn’t care so we need to be ahead of it.
PATIENT: I’m with you.
DOCTOR: Because you know it was nasty when we started.
FAMILY MEMBER: I know.
DOCTOR: And we had to-.
PATIENT: Well, how can I get rid of it completely, though?
DOCTOR: Well, we’re going to find out to see if it’s waking up. You’ve had everything under the sun thus far.
FAMILY MEMBER: Right.
DOCTOR: We will continue to be as aggressive. If there is something new, we’re probably going to take a sample of that.
PATIENT: Um hum.
DOCTOR: And see what that looks like. Check it again for profiling, blueprinting of your genetics, I mean the whole nine yards.
PATIENT: Okay.
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: We talked about that earlier.
FAMILY MEMBER: Right.
DOCTOR: This is great.
FAMILY MEMBER: Yeah.
DOCTOR: And you’re making music again?
FAMILY MEMBER: Right.
PATIENT: I am, totally.
DOCTOR: I mean, that, you know?
PATIENT: I’m having fun.
DOCTOR: That’s a scale. I mean that’s amazing. Wow. When you’re talented, you’re talented.
PATIENT: Yeah.
DOCTOR: And there’s nothing like cancer that’s going to stop you.
FAMILY MEMBER: No.
PATIENT: No. It ain’t going to stop me. I’ve got to do what I’ve got to do. It ain’t going to stop me. I’ve got to be a superstar. It’s not going to stop me.
PATIENT: Now that I’ll get you and we’ll shoot a video.
DOCTOR: Oh.

DOCTOR: Oh, man. Yes! Let’s do it! You got to give me a heads up.

DOCTOR: You got to do it. So when you walk out, right where you checked in, they will give you the times that’s convenient to both of you.
FAMILY MEMBER: Oh, okay.
DOCTOR: They will scan and go when you’re done.
PATIENT: We can’t go in the waiting room. We’ve still got a video to shoot.
DOCTOR: Yeah. We’ve got a video to shoot. Yeah. (Laughter)
DOCTOR: Oh, they’re ready for you, for your next take. I’ll take my paper now.
PATIENT: I’ll see you later.
PATIENT: Okay.
HEALTHCARE PROFESSIONAL: So there’s a little bit of progression there that maybe…
DOCTOR: It’s a movement you know.
HEALTHCARE PROFESSIONAL: …we’ll do something different for you. Okay.
DOCTOR: Yeah so I’m thinking we’re always trying to not be behind.
PATIENT: Right, right..
DOCTOR: Like every single time when you started the first day I met you we’re always behind the cancer.
PATIENT: Yeah.
DOCTOR: Stuff happens and I’m reactive.
PATIENT: Stop doctor, we’re not saying that word no more.
DOCTOR: Sorry about that. We’re always behind the thing.

PATIENT: Right.
PATIENT: Right.
DOCTOR: For folks just like you.
PATIENT: Right.

PATIENT: Okay.
DOCTOR: And tiredness isn’t that your brain isn’t functioning, functioning great.
PATIENT: Just physically tired?

DOCTOR: Physically tired and it’s a weirder tired not like you worked out in the yard for twelve hours and can’t do much, it’s just no get up and go. If that happens, we take a break and we reduce the medicine dose.

DOCTOR: Yes.
PATIENT: Can we, can we provide a pill that would give me a little, like a vitamin that would give me a little energy?
DOCTOR: No I think the issue of you not having as much energy is that your cancer is starting to, sorry that your thing is starting to break through slowly,
PATIENT: Right.
PATIENT: Yeah.
DOCTOR: but you probably won’t even know what’s going on.

PATIENT: -and the reason why I say this.

PATIENT: That is correct.

PATIENT: Right.

PATIENT: Right.
PATIENT: Okay so what do we do? And the reason why…

PATIENT: Yeah.
HEALTHCARE PROFESSIONAL: Okay.
PATIENT: Okay and I get a good night’s sleep. I wake up the next morning I’m able to walk.
HEALTHCARE PROFESSIONAL: Good.

DOCTOR: So what happens is I go through the insurance. They go through a third party vendor. So Diplomate, CVS Caremark, whatever one your insurance you know sends me to.

You know I know he loves it and this is something he just has to work out by himself and also with you guys. There’s no real medical reason technically and it’s gonna take us a week or two to get that medicine, so there’s time. He says he’s not gonna stay down in F____.

DOCTOR: Yeah.

HEALTHCARE PROFESSIONAL 2: Ummmmm.

PATIENT: Right.

DOCTOR: But it’s a start. So, what does that tell us? It’s aggressive, but we know that about your cancer. But, if we don’t talk about surgery as an option, then we didn’t do right by you because you know that that’s a possibility. What’s the root of all that? Well, it’s your cancer not controlled. That’s always the root of all evil. Not your bones, but your lymph nodes are growing. So, in this –
PATIENT: So what’s goin’ on, so what’s goin’ on with my bones?
DOCTOR: Nothin’.
PATIENT: He just said that somethin’ was goin’ on with my bones.
HEALTHCARE PROFESSIONAL 1: No. I didn’t say anything.

HEALTHCARE PROFESSIONAL 1: Oh.

HEALTHCARE PROFESSIONAL 1: He had progression on his bone scan and CAT scan. That’s what he might have gone through.
DOCTOR: Oh, could be. But his bones are not progressed. It’s just the, um, lymph nodes. (Pause)
PATIENT: No.

DOCTOR: I’m the one bringin’ it up because I see it on the scan. Oh!! We gotta do something. We gotta do something. But, from a functional day-to-day, it’s not really buggin’ you. If you were peeing poop, it would bug you. You would know it. It would frighten the heck out of everybody, but that’s not what’s happening. So, here’s a chance where we can proactively think about it and not wait until it’s an emergency.
PATIENT: I’m not peeing poop.
PATIENT: Yeah.
DOCTOR: Don’t –
PATIENT: And I can just –
DOCTOR: Don’t aggravate!
PATIENT: Tell the difference. I can tell the difference.
DOCTOR: Oh, yeah. And we know you’re okay now ‘cuz we know when you’re not okay because it’s not subtle.
PATIENT: Yeah.
DOCTOR: When you’re not okay, you’re just being – peeing gobs of blood, tissue – we know you’re not okay. That’s not happening right now. So, we’re at this perfect window –
PATIENT: Right.
DOCTOR: Where we gotta make a decision –
PATIENT: So okay, doc. So, let me --
DOCTOR: And that’s the key.
PATIENT: Let me ask you this.
DOCTOR: Yeah.
PATIENT: Okay. I have an ache in my hands.

DOCTOR: Mm,hmm.

DOCTOR: Well, it’s a change, you know. It’s just this, this cancer’s just letting you know that it’s doin’ it’s thing every step of the way. You haven’t had two seconds of a break, and it’s hard. And I know one thing you love to do is ride your bike, and it’s hard to do when things aren’t right down there. Whether it’s pain or –
PATIENT: Well, doc, you know --
DOCTOR: Incontinence or whatever.
PATIENT: Okay. So, no, no. Here, here’s the deal.

PATIENT: Okay.
DOCTOR: I don’t think it’s –

DOCTOR: Yes!

DOCTOR: Oh, yeah. Yeah. You’ll be fine.
PATIENT: Oh, man! No!!! Doc! C’mon!
DOCTOR: You’ll be fine!
PATIENT: F*** you sayin’?
DOCTOR: One pee, one poop.
PATIENT: Oh, hell, no, doc!
DOCTOR: That’s what – this is what I’m sayin’.
PATIENT: But will I – wait a minute, wait a minute, wait a minute, but Dr. P_ just talked about one bag! And you come out with two bags, man!
DOCTOR: Well, you might need two bags.
PATIENT: Woooooooo.
DOCTOR: Where’s the bowel gonna get re-routed? It’s gotta poop somewhere, and you’re got a connection.
PATIENT: Wooooooo.

PATIENT: Oh, doc! That ain’t – ohhhh, doc! That’s a stanky situation, doc!
DOCTOR: I – pfffff – this is why I know you, Mr. L_!
PATIENT: So that, so that’ll cover that.
DOCTOR: Yes.

DOCTOR: If you – well, you may not need it.
